maml:description.maml:para: Returns SnapShots for one or more VM(s).

Returns one or more MSVM_VirtualSystemSettingData WMI object(s) representing snapshots. An individual snapshot can be selected by specifying its name, and the newest snapshot can be selected by specifying the -Newest switch.

The Virtual Machine(s) to query . This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is passed, all VMs on the server are queried.
The name of a snapshot to return.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
If Specified only the newest Snapshot is returned.
If specified only the root snapshot is returned.
If specified only the current snapshot is returned.

The Virtual Machine(s) to query . This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe. If no VM is passed, all VMs on the server are queried.
The name of a snapshot to return.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
If Specified only the newest Snapshot is returned.
if specified only the root snapshot is returned.
If specified only the current snapshot is returned.
Virtual Machines can be piped into Get-VMSnapshot.
Object(s) representing the snapshot(s) of the VM(s).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the newest snapshot on the VM pointed to by $core.

maml:description.maml:para: Displays all the Snapshots of a VM in a tree view.
The function displays the snapshots of a Single Virtual machine, arranged in tree format to make it easy to see which snapshots are descended from which others.

The Virtual Machine to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), It may be passed via the pipe, but must be a single item.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.

The Virtual Machine to query. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), It may be passed via the pipe, but must be a single item.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
Virtual Machines can be piped into Get-VMSnapshotTree.
Creates a new snapshot of one more VMs.
Creates a new snapshot of one more VMs.

The Virtual Machine(s) to snapshot. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
Sets an explanatory note on the snapshot.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
If the wait switch is specified the function will display a progress indicator until the job completes.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").

The Virtual Machine(s) to snapshot. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
Sets an explanatory note on the snapshot.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
If the wait switch is specified the function will display a progress indicator until the job completes.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
Virtual Machines can be piped into New-VMSnapshot.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Takes a snapshot of the VM pointed to by $core.
Gets the VMs with names beginning "Core" on the server "James-2008" and snapshots them one by one.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes one or more snapshots from a VM.
Removes one or more snapshots from a VM.
An Object representing the snapshot to be removed - may be passed via the pipeline..
If specified remove-VMSnapshot will remove snapshots which are children of the selected one..
If the wait switch is specified the function will display a progress indicator until the job completes.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
An Object representing the snapshot to be removed - may be passed via the pipeline..
If specified remove-VMSnapshot will remove snapshots which are children of the selected one..
If the wait switch is specified the function will display a progress indicator until the job completes.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
Snapshots can be piped into Remove-VMSnapshot.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Prompts the user to select a snapshot on the VM pointed to by $core, and removes it, and any child snapshots.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes the display name of a snapshot.
Changes the display name of a snapshot.

The Virtual Machine(s) whose snapshot(s) should be renamed. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. Unlike most commands, Rename-VMSnapShot DOES NOT allow VMs to be passed via the pipeline - pipeline input expects snapshot objects.
The old name of the snapshot.
The new name of the snapshot.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
An Object representing the snapshot to be renamed. Only a single snapshot can be passed as a parameter, but multiple snapshots may be passed via the pipeline.
The new name of the snapshot.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").

The Virtual Machine(s) whose snapshot(s) should be renamed. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. Unlike most commands, Rename-VMSnapShot DOES NOT allow VMs to be passed via the pipeline - pipeline input expects snapshot objects.
The old name of the snapshot.
The new name of the snapshot.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
An Object representing the snapshot to be renamed. Only a single snapshot can be passed as a parameter, but multiple snapshots may be passed via the pipeline.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
SnapShots can be piped into Rename-Snapshot.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Prompts the user to select one of the snap shots on the VM pointed to by $core and renames it to “default”.

maml:description.maml:para: Rolls a VM back (or forward) to a snapshot.
Rolls a VM back (or forward) to a snapshot.
An Object representing one or more snapshots to be applied - may be passed via the pipeline.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
Restarts the VM(s) after completion of the restoration(s).
If the wait switch is specified the function will display a progress indicator until the restoration completes.
An Object representing one or more snapshots to be applied - may be passed via the pipeline.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. This command has a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
Restarts the VM(s) after completion of the restoration(s).
If the wait switch is specified the function will display a progress indicator until the restoration completes.
Snapshots can be piped into Restore-VMsnapshot.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Lets the user select a snapshot on the VM pointed to by $core and applies it.
Gets snapshots named "Monday" made on any VM on the local server and restores them without prompting.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: ApplyVirtualSystemSnapshot Method of the MsVM_VirtualSystemManagementService Class on MSDN

maml:description.maml:para: Allows the user to select a snapshot for a VM.
If there is only a single snapshot it is returned, if there is more than one a tree view of the snapshots for the VM is displayed for the user to make a selection.

The Virtual Machine to query This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches a single VM). It may be passed via the pipe. Only a single VM may be queried.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.

The Virtual Machine to query This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches a single VM). It may be passed via the pipe. Only a single VM may be queried.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
The desired virtual machine can be piped into select-VMSnapshot.
An MSVM_VirtualSystemSettingData object representing a snapshot.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the Snapshots of the machine pointed to by $core and if there are multiple snap shots prompts the user to select one from a tree.

maml:description.maml:para: Replaces an existing snapshot with a new one.

This function is a wrapper for New-Snapshot, remove-Snapshot, and rename-snapshot. If no snapshot name is specified the function gets the most recent snapshot. It renames that snapshot to “Delete-me”. It creates a new snapshot, using the note if one is specified, and renames the new snapshot to the given name. Finally it removes the old version of the snapshot..

The Virtual Machine(s) on which the snapshot should be updated. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.
The name of the snapshot to update. If no name is provided the newest snapshot is used (and its name re-used).
A note to add to the newly created snapshot.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. Update-VMSnapShot calls other commands which have a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").

The Virtual Machine(s) on which the snapshot should be updated. This may be a WMI object representing a VM, a string object containing the name of a VM (or a wildcard which matches multiple VMs), or an array containing a mixture of such objects. It may be passed via the pipe.cd.
The name of the snapshot to update. If no name is provided the newest snapshot is used (and its name re-used).
A note to add to the newly created snapshot.
Specifies the Hyper-V server on which a named Virtual Machine resides. By default "." , the local computer, is used. An array of server names may be passed but wildcards can not be used.
THIS PARAMETER SHOULD NEVER BE PASSED FROM THE COMMAND LINE. It is used to ensure correct handling of -Whatif, -confirm, -verbose etc., with nested and recursive calls to the command.

Ensures that the user is not prompted before the action is carried out. Update-VMSnapShot calls other commands which have a "ConfirmImpact" level of High: so the default is to request confirmation (unless the $confirmPreference variable is set to "none").
Virtual Machines can be piped into Update-VMSnapshot.
